instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not getting to S5 state
threads.message:
Good morning,

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not getting into the S5 state


[B]Device history: [/B]
Liquid damage near USB C connector area. Hole burned into the board under connector. Shorting <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL>. No matter how much I dug, i was not able to relieve this short. So, instead of continuing to dig into this board, I decided to bypass this line. What I did was remove the corresponding CD, mask the 4 pads under the CD for this line, then ran jumper from <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> under the CD. 

This got me to 20v.

[B]Current state:[/B]
Currently the device is drawing 20v at about 100mA.

[B]Power Rails: [/B]
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>: 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>: 1.8
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>: 2.5v
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>: 5v

So, it looks like <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, is this correct? Also, are there other prerequisites for the s5 rails to come alive? 

Thanks for the advice

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not getting to S5 state
threads.message:
Possibly data lines damaged on the burnt area.

Check first if machine is at least detected in DFU mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not getting to S5 state
threads.message: It is not detected in DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not getting to S5 state
threads.message:
2W of power when off sounds high. Maybe still a short to ground on some power rail.
T2 is at least partially working if USB-PD at 20V is negotiated, should be enough to get DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not getting to S5 state
threads.message:
If cannot get into DFU, should be a problem with T2 chip then.
Not worth to waste time.
You cannot get into S5, if T2 doesn't properly work.
Try to follow the exact steps in the DFU tutorials linked on the forum.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not getting to S5 state
